discussion.p: `ranges` namespace is used inconsistently in . One example is:

blockquote.pre: template<random_access_range R, class Comp = ranges::less, class Proj = identity> requires sortable<iterator_t<R>, Comp, Proj> constexpr borrowed_iterator_t<R> ranges::push_heap(R&& r, Comp comp = {}, Proj proj = {});

discussion.p: where we can see `ranges::` before `push_heap` name itself, also before `less` but not before `random_access_range`. It's all over the place. The same is with `sort`:

blockquote.pre: template<random_access_range R, class Comp = ranges::less, class Proj = identity> requires sortable<iterator_t<R>, Comp, Proj> constexpr borrowed_iterator_t<R> ranges::sort(R&& r, Comp comp = {}, Proj proj = {});

discussion.p: Another example is `for_each` where we don't have `ranges` namespace before `borrowed_iterator_t`:

blockquote.pre: template<input_range R, class Proj = identity, indirectly_unary_invocable<projected<iterator_t<R>, Proj>> Fun> constexpr ranges::for_each_result<borrowed_iterator_t<R>, Fun> ranges::for_each(R&& r, Fun f, Proj proj = {});

discussion.p: There is no clear resolution for that, but during an LWG session is was decided to create an LWG issue for this.
Set priority to 4 after reflector poll.
Recollection of the intended rule was to use `std::` and `ranges::` if the same name is in both namespaces (like `less`, etc.). This is the result of an editorial decision.
